Our leaflet on alcohol and depression contains a drinks tracker and advice on where to go and what to do if you or someone you know is drinking too much: https://t.co/UdM0Eey19V
If you're concerned about your alcohol intake, monitor what you're drinking and seek help from your GP or local addiction services.

It's good news that young people are drinking less, but we have a group of people in their 30s and over who are drinking at higher levels, more so since the pandemic. @rcpsychAddFac @drjmas @DrEJLFinch
Addiction treatment services have lost around a quarter of their funding. This must be addressed if services are to treat the number of people needing help. @drjmas @rcpsychAddFac

Alcohol killed more people last year than at any point in the last two decades @Channel4News @drjmas chair of @rcpsychAddFac says addiction is a complex condition and we need a strategy to address it.

Chair of @rcpsychAddFac @drjmas will be live on @Channel4News tonight to discuss the increase in alcohol-related liver deaths and what needs to happen to ensure more lives aren't needlessly lost. @jamiemroberton @DrEJLFinch https://t.co/XM4g45dJVU

How does a junior doctor end up in an art class in a men‚Äôs prison or acting as a facilitator on a leadership course? #choosepsychiatry 

Read more HERE to find out: https://t.co/6tOq9tyVvK https://t.co/MdZQurrgpj

And that's it! One hour with @FemiMind almost gone in a flash. We've never so many questions + comments says @DrAdrianJames  Thank you Professor Oyebode for a v informative talk. Twitter followers - we will upload the recording on our website + tweet the link. #RCPsychLectures

@FemiMind Virtual versus online interviewing of patients - pros and cons? Having the first meeting face to face is important, says @FemiMind  - you miss things when working online. Running it virtually makes the interaction more democratic - eg patient asks me if I am ok #RCPsychLectures

With delusions increasingly seen as being on a spectrum, is there any use for over valued ideas? "Over valued ideas are complicated + misunderstood but worth hanging onto.. an over valued idea motivates behaviour says @FemiMind #RCPsychLectures

Now we have precise neuro imaging and other modern approaches, is psychopathology now outmoded? a questioner asks - "I am discussing elemental abnormalities" says @FemiMind "and you could not do without psychopathology, it is foundational" #RCPsychLectures

The prototype for understanding hallucination is visual but we rarely see visual cases, and the characteristics of  hallucinations can be v different (eg smell v visual, persistence)... psychopathology is not a glossary at the back of a book @FemiMind #RCPsychLectures
It is time to start to think there's a different way of approaching delusions - but this doesn't only pertain to delusions, you can do it for hallucinations too @FemiMind #RCPsychLectures

We understand the evolutionary background of pathological jealousy - albeit when the person is ill they carry it to extreme levels - this is v different from different from folie a deux @FemiMind explains why understanding mechanisms driving delusions is vital #RCPsychLectures

Envy and jealousy are conceptually different feelings - the behaviours which occur in the context of pathological jealousy are totally understandable in the context of evolutionary biology. Lots to enjoy in the early part of this talk @FemiMind #RCPsychLectures
There are primary and secondary delusions + we can agree on that.  But the mechanisms which make these abnormal judgments occur can be v different, @FemiMind says #RCPsychLectures

One's attitude to their inner world - and their mind - is different from their attitude to their body - if a psychiatrist makes comments about someone's subjective experiences, patients can find that opinion contestable, @FemiMind #RCPsychLectures

Conditions psychiatrists deal with affect the ability of individuals to model the world into the future - such emotions such as hope and time. @FemiMind starts by highlighting the difference between psychiatry and medical care for physical ailments. #RCPsychLectures

We get started as @FemiMind thanks @DrAdrianJames for his introduction, which was a long one, such is former RCPsych Lifetime Achievement Award winner Professor Odeboye's list of achievements! #RCPsychLectures

We're just moments away from the latest in our series of President's lectures - @FemiMind is giving a talk called 'Psychopathology, the Foundational Discipline of Psychiatry' and we have a record 1,144 booked onto the talk - looking forward to this #RCPsychLectures

This event will take place at 5-6pm *today* (10 November) from the @WHO pavilion at #COP26. 

Please join us to learn more about the important connections between climate change and mental health.

Then we will hear from Dr Lynne Jones, a psychiatrist who has worked in disaster zones. She has spoken to many people over the years who‚Äôve survived unimaginable trauma and she recorded testimony from doctors who survived Typhoon Haiyan:

https://t.co/aK0PzeMwpx
We will then hear from Dr Lisa Page, @rcpsych‚Äôs Associate Registrar for Sustainability, who will talk about the mental health implications of climate change, with a focus on heat-related impacts.
Professor Stephen Holgate (@RCPhysicians) will then talk about the growing health impact of pollutants. He will explain how this is exacerbating health inequalities.
Dr Rosie Spooner (@spooner_rosie) from @RCPCHtweets will talk about the impact of climate change on child health and childhood and the need to move to sustainable healthcare.

Professor @davidnabarro now wrapping up this fantastic session organised by @ClimateCares. Thanks to all of the great panelists who took part.

@Emma_L_Lawrance, @Dzennypha, @DrGaryBelkin, @Fahmy__Hanna__ and Dr Lisa Page.
Panelists asked what they would like to see happen after this session. The response from @rcpsych‚Äôs Dr Lisa Page: https://t.co/cIOJNrpUkN

Dr Lisa Page: It might seem obvious and inevitable to us that there are links between climate change and mental health. But this is not the case for policy makers. We need to emphasise the link to help make it obvious for policy makers.

Question from audience: What work is being done to measure and record the mental health effects of climate change?

Dr @Emma_L_Lawrance: Many of the impacts of climate change on mental health are ‚Äòhidden costs‚Äô and are not being accounted for. We need to make them tangible.

Lisa Page: Some of the mental health impacts of storms, floods etc are significant. It leads to lots of practical issues to sort out. We need to do things that support and promote resilience and we need to have systems in place to deal with mental health problems as they arise.
Professor @davidnabarro now introducing the panel which includes @RCPsych‚Äôs Dr Lisa Page, our Associate Registrar for Sustainability https://t.co/lUM3elIC5t
EL asking for where people currently find hope: https://t.co/u2jb3JdSsC
Jennifer from Nigeria ‚ÄúWe need to be just with our climate decisions ‚Ä¶ we need to recognise the loss and damage happening to ‚Ä¶ people of colour all around the world.‚Äù

Dr @Emma_L_Lawrance (Mental Health Innovations Fellow at @Imperial_IGHI) now moving on to the solutions that people want to see.

‚ÄúI want to go outside and be able to breathe‚Äù - Kadisha

EL: Examples of common solutions include having more green and blue spaces is good for mental health and trees and water help to reduce temperature extremes. 

Also, increasing provision of walking and cycling facilities improves wellbeing and reduces air and noise pollution.
EL: There are common causes between climate change and mental health. This means that there are win-win opportunities in finding common solutions.
More thoughts shared: https://t.co/r4djPC9q1G
Participants sharing details of how climate change makes them feel. https://t.co/o8R5zrxarm

A reminder that the College has factsheets on ‚Äòeco distress‚Äô to help you understand and deal with anxiety about environmental issues.

https://t.co/MmzYGz8KOR

We are now hearing personal testimonies from people around the world who have been, and continue to be, affected by climate change. 

‚ÄúAt times climate change makes me feel overwhelmed‚Äù - Tassia, Australia
EL: Climate change threatens to widen inequalities in mental health. This is all part of a wider complex system. https://t.co/lHlowDs4U3
EL: In a survey of 2,000 young people from around the world, 73% said they are very worried about the the state of the planet right now and 56% think humanity is doomed.
EL: Increases in temperatures, e.g. due to heatwaves, lead to increases in suicide. Media often focuses on the economic cost of extreme climatic events, but not on the psychological effects.
Lots of ways that this leads to effects on mental health. https://t.co/n8C88NKE4T
EL: We are seeing more extreme climate events. These have implications for livelihood and culture, e.g. loss of habitats, community breakdown, disruption of healthcare systems etc.

Dr @Emma_L_Lawrance makes the point that most people don‚Äôt make the connection between climate change and #MentalHealth.

Climate change is a mental health emergency.

"There's been a significant rise in demand for services treating children and young people and treating people with eating disorders," says @subodhdave1
"There's been a lack of parity of esteem and things have improved but this is off the back of decades of chronic underfunding," says @subodhdave1

"1.5 million people are now waiting for mental health treatment. Pressures in one area affect pressures in another area. If people are waiting they may get more unwell and put greater pressure on the NHS," says Dean @subodhdave1
"This has been a long-standing problem. This is why we launched the #ChoosePsychiatry campaign to improve this situation," says Dean @subodhdave1

Dr. Clarke finishes off by saying that humans are remarkable and the pandemic pushed us to show love in a way we hadn't seen before.
In conclusion, Dr. Clarke talks about learning about human nature and the way we, as humans, loved one another, and the kindness we exhibited during tough and arduous times.
- That same attitude wasn't limited to the NHS, this same behaviour was exhibited around the nation with various acts of humanity
- When push came to shove, our grizzled tenacity shone through. We had a determination to showcase love no matter what

Dr Clarke next talk about the three things she learned from the pandemic:

- Human connection, the way we care about patients and showcase love, especially in environments that prevented contact/touch

Dr. Clarke talks about reclaiming love and how NHS staff were able to transmit love despite the preventative measures of the pandemic. It was easier to not go the extra mile than it was to make that extra effort to help patients in such difficult times.

Dr. Clarke mentions 'Nick' and the risks she took, by making contact with a very ill patient, and the act of reclaiming her humanity. 'Nick' did take the necessary steps following this by showering and ensuring that she took the necessary steps following contact with said patient
Dr. Clarke despite being somewhat used to death, it was something that was hard to cope with, she needed support. The daily conditions of work felt wrong and indecent.

Inhumanity is the common link shared by these stories. Dr. Clarke says that a lot of the measures in place violated some of the things that made us human. Nobody should die alone, yet during the pandemic, this occurred over and over again.

Dr. Clarke mentions a colleague, 'Nick' while describing a situation with a distressed patient. 'Nick' chose to touch the patient, who was profoundly distressed, thus breaking rules. However, 'Nick' cradled the patient thus breaking this state of distress.
Dr. Clarke now describes PPE and the inevitable dehumanising aspect of the process of, first wearing PPE and then helping the family of patients into PPE, especially children

Dr. Clarke describes how it was to be on Covid wards. The first thing that struck her was how empty hospital car parks. The cars that were there usually pointed towards the hospital buildings, the owners of the cars were usually loved ones who weren't permitted to enter hospitals
Dr. Clarke then covers the state we were in 18 months ago. Journalists described an apocalyptic state, which many shared. There a frantic and chaotic state across many of our services.
Dr. Clarke talks about processing experiences. The multiplication of individual experiences. What one person experienced could be the same for millions worldwide.

There are many different types of students who could have benefited from SM and access to online resources and more. He acknowledges that if social media existed in the '80s the issues we face would still be prevalent, however, there'd be just as many people who would benefit.

There's an independent aspect to young people and social media. They can learn how to cook, as well as learn about current affairs. These are benefits that create new roles for them to get into in both social life and prospective careers.
Social media allows young people to have fun and be creative. Platforms such as @tiktok_uk / @tiktok_us have allowed young people to develop new skills and in some instances develop careers.

Social media does enable young people to develop different communication skills. In the modern world, you need to understand how to connect with people online, something that has become a key social skill.

He talks about the various challenges young people endure, and how these core challenges are still the same despite social media. Children still experience things such as the emotions of upholding friendships and going through puberty.
Next up to speak is @Psycle_Doc to speak on the 'brighter side' of social media and young people's #mentalhealth. https://t.co/TG6wiYhb8A
@saraevanslacko steers the conversation towards the mental health care of children and adolescents living in deprived areas of Brazil #RCPsychIC

He concludes by saying, our young people are going to be online, and we can't stop that. Adult need to understand the seriousness of online content. He moves onto Covid 19 and how social media changed during lockdown periods and some of the positive stories. Young people were able to keep in touch despite not being able to see each other, something that had a positive effect on their mental health.
He talks about the Online Safety bill. https://t.co/DBXLlmNPnf

What are the possible solutions? He says that adults (parents) need to educate themselves, open their eyes and establish communications with young people to get a better understanding of what they're going through and their experiences. https://t.co/BDNKw9ZvJH

Social Media companies are deliberately manipulating the algorithms to increase our use. Techniques such as data mining, notifications, and variable reinforcement are all geared to keep people online and upping screen time.

Young people are exposed to things such as inappropriate exposure, grooming, and contact with people/platforms at an alarmingly young age. He mentions the new platform @OnlyFans which is very concerning as underage girls are accessing the platform by dodging flimsy ID checks. https://t.co/Ze4aOEXcae

@FemiMind thanks @MichaelRosenYes for his brilliant talk here at #RCPsychIC. He talks about the power of family, love, and music, and the impact it has on the healing and recovery process.

He talks about the uneasy relationship between his mind and his body. He uses the analogy of going to the shop and forgetting to buy humous. The feeling of staring at the fridge and knowing that there's something missing.
He described the feeling of postponing death, something he says life felt like, a constant postponement of death. He would remind people "I'm not dead, I am alive!"
He continues reading, describing a tweet he replied to referring to somebody's claims that the many covid stories were fallacies, to which he replied "I made it all up, I was hiding under the table".
He described the nurses presented him with the patient diary. He read the many entries which described how the nurses who looked after him, almost as if they were parents.
He described losing sight in his left eye and hearing in his left ear, something he instantly felt upon waking up from his coma.
He continues reading, describing how he learned to walk 3 times. first, as a child, then when he was 17 after being hit by a card, and having to rehabilitate in Watford, and then after COVID.
He called his grey walking 'Sticky McStick Stick'. He continues reading, describing how many before him went through the same process. He then reads about death and how his mother died.

He continues reading, describing his recovery process. He had to learn how to walk again, with the aide of physio. A process that proved difficult as he had low blood pressure. Their expectation didn't match what he could do.

He's reminded of the moment before he was put under.  A doctor asked him to sign papers while being told he had a 50/50 chance of surviving. 

He talks about dreamlike hallucinations which involve being comforted by Dr Emma.
He mentions being awake in Whittington Hospital, located in Archway, in the Northside of London, overlooking the whole city.

Dr. Emma, wrote to his family concerned about his condition. They didn't know what the lasting impacts would be. Would he be brain dead?

The game-changer was allowing Dr. Emma into the atrium, something which broke COVID protocols. Something that resulted in him waking up.
He was okay at the start, but after a week his condition worsened, which resulted in him being induced into a coma. During those 40 days, of which he'd have no recollection, the nurses kept a diary.
He describes being ill, his wife called a neighbour, Dr Emma, to check on him. He talks about coming to terms with having the illness once hearing how low his blood oxygen level was.
He starts by reading from his book "Many different kinds of love" about his experience with #COVID19.  He says to wrote as the words came to him and not necessarily thinking about being coherent.
Welcome to this Keynote "Coming to terms with COVID: Many different kinds of love" at #RCPsychIC by author and poet  @MichaelRosenYes, who is introduced by our very own @FemiMind.

"Ensuring appropriate mental health support on release is a big issue. Many prisoners are of no fixed abode on release," says Dr Holloway @rcpsychForensic
@petrus_cmty @GMMH_NHS

"Around 10% of the current prison population could have missed out on a community sentence or a suspended prison sentence with a Mental Health Treatment Requirement," says Dr Josanne Holloway @rcpsychForensic
"One of the key ways we can get a better picture of mental health need within prisons is through better screening on reception," says Dr Holloway @rcpsychForensic
"Delays in being transferred to a secure bed will lead to a worsening of the condition, a worsening of symptoms, but also distress for the family," says Dr Holloway @rcpsychForensic

"To address racial disparities in mental health services and the criminal justice system, we need better education, we need to address barriers to services in the community and we need to be better at identifying mental health need," says Dr Holloway @rcpsychForensic
"The prison environment may have a negative environment on mental health and wellbeing, but steps can be taken to mitigate against this," says Dr Holloway @rcpsychForensic

Thank you very much @DavidLammy MP for your time and the insightful discussion. We were very honoured to have you @raj_psyc @DrLadeSmith.
The mental health of minority communities is central to progress. Despite the tough circumstances there is hope and there is a generational shift that will lead to better outcomes in the future.

Issues of class and race combine and create a blockade for people from minority backgrounds and specially Black youth to elite educational institutes. Understanding the difference between elite and elitist institutions is key to improve access to top universities and jobs.
The system was almost unaware of the issues minority staff faced within the NHS. This was highlighted after the disproportionate minority staff deaths during Covid.
There is a generational shift in millennial attitudes and hopefully blips like the controversial findings of the CRED report are few and far between as younger people take the lead in the future.

When a privileged person is using cannabis recreationally in a gated community vs when a young Black person does it in Tottenham the policing outcomes are vastly different. There are no seconds chances for Black people.
And white colleagues educating themselves. The dialogue and discussion taking place in organisations like @rcpsych gives him hope for better outcomes for Black and Minority Ethnic people.

.@DrLadeSmith asks about early intervention before youth end up in the Criminal Justice system. Mr Lammy emphasises the need to acknowledge systemic racism. He sees hope in actions taken by FTSE 100 companies, public sector and charity institutions to improve diversity

If recommendations in the Lammy review were implemented we wouldn‚Äôt be in a worse position than 2017. There has been a rise to 53% over representation of BAME youth in prison since the Lammy review.

There seems to be a generational shift led by Black communities, younger people and progressives to highlight systemic racism and discuss the treatment of Black people and communities in wider society.

Staying at home and working from home during Covid meant we couldn‚Äôt look away and divert attention from the killing of George Floyd. That attention led to the conversations about race we had as a country and society.

What can be done internationally? As psychiatrists in all the countries we need to come together + remember we all got into this profession to take care of all patients, whatever some governments believe + the US, UK + others need to do more + take a strong stance @SaulLevinMD

Whenever you come to our meetings @DrAdrianJames you always remember LGBTQI people, and the @rcpsych CEO Paul Rees is always happy to share the progressive work the Royal College is doing - we stand as beacons of light. Kind words from @SaulLevinMD #rcpsychlectures

The @APAPsychiatric works to make sure LGBTQ people have a voice in our organisation and in society at large, so in the future our health system is best placed to treat the most diverse range of patients and provide culturally competent care. Great talk from @SaulLevinMD

The APA now has a strong position against conversion therapy, we are a v different organisation. I want to thank the World Psychiatric Association and @dineshbhugra + each president since then for struggling for equality for the LGBT community @SaulLevinMD #rcpsychlectures

The APA historically highlighted homosexuality as an illness, and it took people to stand up to make change. In 1972 John Fryer, a psychiatrist + gay activist, told an APA meeting "you need to look at your psychiatrists because we're part of you." A big moment #rcpsychlectures

Today the majority of openly gay psychiatrists can practice without fear that it will affect their careers says @SaulLevinMD - but what did the earlier APA do to pathologise homosexuality in the past? An engrossing talk so far #rcpsychlectures

In 2013 I was appointed to CEO + MD of American Psychiatric Association and began work to dismantle the structural racism within the APA - we need to do this correctly after 400 years of racism in USA + need our staff to be more representative of APA + population @SaulLevinMD

Homophobia like racism remains a problem across the world says @SaulLevinMD - I had to overcome prejudice from an early age, whether it was my accent or being a gay man. Dr Levin grew up in South Africa where under Apartheid being gay was illegal #rcpsychlectures

Our CEO Paul Rees has 'changed the house of medicine' both in the UK and in America where they are following some of the transformational things @rcpsych has adopted @SaulLevinMD tells #rcpsychlectures

We're just minutes away from the latest in our series of President's lectures. Today we're delighted to welcome @SaulLevinMD CEO + Medical Director @APAPsychiatric - whose talk is titled 'The LGBTQ Journey in Psychiatry and the American Psychiatric Association' #rcpsychlectures

Dr Page ends with "what's good for our planet is also good for our patients."
Here's what you can do in your workplace: https://t.co/tsHQH2iUWh
This slide illustrates the principles of Sustainable Practice. Sustainable healthcare is also good quality healthcare. https://t.co/Y3Va7OB4Ob
Some of the indirect effects are already being seen in the younger generation.

She talks about how this impacts our #mentalhealth. The direct effects are things like change in weather (floods, storms, droughts, wildfires), which then leads on to changes in landscape and displacements, which in turn lead to implications on mental health.

She starts by talking about the severity of climate and ecological emergencies. She focuses on the tipping points, some of which we've already crossed such as, the melting of the Arctic Sea Ice and West Antarctic Ice sheet, and large scale die offs of coral reefs.
Next up is Dr Lisa Page to talk about the Implications of the Climate and Ecological Emergencies for Psychiatrists.
All of these things will help the NHS become the world's first net-zero emissions health service. #EarthDay

He talks about how the NHS will go about achieving this. Greener vehicles, making commitments to act now not later, funding new net zero clinical fellowships, and many more things that will be revisited and reviewed. https://t.co/ccxtAkBjcX

This graphic shows the current carbon footprint of the NHS. It shows where we can reduce emissions. The NHS hopes to become the world's first zero emissions health service; an ambitious but achievable goal. 2040 for the things they control directly and 2045 for the full scope. https://t.co/OCZXVPDRgY
"There are serious health impacts from climate change. They are dangerous and worrying. You cannot provide high quality care for all, now and for the future, if you don't tackle climate change."
Up next us Nick Watts from NHS England for his talk on 'Delivering a Net Zero NHS'
- LEAD BY PERSONAL EXAMPLE!

Here are some of the things YOU can do:
- Become informed and share information
- Get involved in how your org is responding
- Get your org to disinvest from fossil fuels
- Get your org to declare a climate emergency 
- Review your own clinical pathway and waste management
The impact on health is evident. By phasing out fossil fuels we can prevent 3.6 million premature deaths as a result.

She also talks about the ecological emergency. Natural habitats around the world are at risk of being destroyed as a result of climate change. She talks about the links between climate change and the global threat to health.
The impacts of climate change is evident around the world. If we don't adapt to climate change, we could see 85 deaths per 100,000 people by the year 2100 as a result.

Fiona Goldee from The BMJ is our first speaker to talk about Climate Emergency. She starts her talk with global temperature change, something that has been increasing year on year. She also covers Global CO2 emissions over the past century, which has been rising.

Clinicians for Climate Action webinar begins with 70% of members in attendance saying acting on climate and ecological crisis should be a part of their job @UKHealthClimate #EarthDay2021 https://t.co/vyX2QiYPPb
The Clinicians for Climate Action free Webinar is now taking place. Today you will hear about  the benefits of change and how psychiatrists can contribute. #EarthDay #EarthDay2021

In response to @dean4watford  Dr Davidson @Psychautismcham says that people with autism should have a strength based plan to help plan for their care focused on how they can achieve what they want in life. It should be flexible as what you want to achieve as a teenager may change

Dr Courtenay @psychiatryofid says there should be a clear contract between the clinician and the inpatient LD unit when someone is admitted so it is clear why they are being admitted and a plan for how they can be supported in the community once they leave

Dr Davidson @Psychautismcham says there are huge benefits to a system which focuses much more on community services rather than inpatient care. The advantage of the Trieste model is that when they shut down asylums the money went to community services.

.@wavetrust says parity of esteem between mental and physical health has a very long way to go. There would be outrage if a patient with a broken leg received the same treatment as a patient needing mental health treatment and support.

Now @Cruickshan3Andy shares more about the Tower Hamlets Violence Reduction Collaborative project. The project successfully reduced levels of violent incidents across acute admissions wards and psychiatric intensive care units.

Dr Jorge Zimbron, Consultant psychiatrist at Fulbourn Hospital shares the new Springbank model based on positive risk taking. His work has led to zero restraint and tranquillisation on his unit. Courage, empathy and compassion are safer than risk containment he says.

The group hears from a lived experience partner. She shares her own experience of services. Her childhood wasn‚Äôt considered to understand her conditions. She appreciates that the MHA white paper proposes changes to nearest relative role and allows her more privacy.

Dr Gregoire tells the meeting children  depressed at 16 all had mothers who were depressed, mainly at the perinatal stage. Generation Alpha have the evidence to break ancient cycles of ill health and misery associated with ACEs.

President of @MMHAlliance and perinatal consultant psychiatrist Dr Alain Gregoire says adverse childhood experiences are the number 1 predictor for mental and physical illness later in life. It is the emotional context of ACEs that have long term harm.

@Rachel_Luby helped create the Sexual Standards for mental health wards and leads the 'Lets Talk About Sex' campaign, listen to her on our latest podcast and find out more https://t.co/IJ0nlpogGU https://t.co/wY40pwaJrp
If you did miss this President's lecture but you'd like to catch up with it, we will be publishing the video on https://t.co/RRCMu29RX0

Recognise you're there to help, says @johnballatt. Listen to what ppl are saying, and try to be soothing, trust if you do you might get something back, says Dr Maloney. Acknowledge your fears, says @CamplingPenny.
If you have one minute with the Sec of State for Health - what 3 things would you ask them to do? @DrAdrianJames poses a big last question...

How can we cope with social distancing when being in groups are so important - we've lost the animal contact with ppl, says Dr Maloney. Zoom is good at transmitting ideas but not close interaction. Perhaps we need to introduce online versions of those little physical moments.

Does the culture of scapegoating relate to agonic and hedonic models, someone asks. Scapegoating has been happening in tribes, communities, through history - but the blame culture we live in has issues with authority + how bosses blame people rather than systems @Johnballatt

Will the pandemic lead to innate fears of germs for generations to come? It's well rooted already among people generally, says Chris Maloney. We may need to learn how to exist in groups together, says @CamplingPenny

Our audience of 550 now get a chance to ask Qs - are there any studies which show groups moving from agonic to hedonic ways, an audience member asks. That's not easy, is the answer, but valuing soothing affiliation + calming things with some agonic action cd be the right blend.

We should work together to acknowledge this and do something to help involving the NHS, education, government and orgs like @rcpsych - we need an inclusive national strategy now, says @johnballatt - we need to face our fears together as honestly as we can. Powerful stuff.

Children, single parents, members of minority ethnic groups, are among the groups who will be experiencing heightened anxiety lasting beyond the pandemic, says @johnballatt - how do we respond as a society?

We need to acknowledge our fear - failure to do so means turning a blind eye to the lived experience of patients and staff. More time needs to be put to the relationships within teams, we need an environment which builds solidary, empathy + care, says @Johnballatt

He refers to a psychiatrist who works with scarce resources in non pandemic times. Conflict is rising in her workplace - she doesn't feel safe at work. Some anxiety can be helpful to make you attentive, but anxiety/fear can lead to despair, + lead to burnout, @johnballatt says.

Our third speaker in this excellent President's lecture is @JohnBallatt who says the experience of intensive care staff during the pandemic is an extreme example, but we can all learn from them, whatever we do.

In an agonic culture, relationships are hierarchical: a culture of fear exists where group members watch their backs. They're good for keeping order, while hedonic cultures can struggle under pressure. Is best approach to blend an agonic and hedonic approach? @CamplingPenny

Everyone is affected by the number and manner of COVID deaths, and the unpredictability of someone suddenly deteriorating, says @CamplingPenny - fear of death, of being a moral failure, of making a mistake are a lot to deal with, does the agonic/hedonic model help us with this?

The patients arrive in hospital with fear in their eyes; nurses experience panic attacks - are they linked to the patients gasping for breath? Does this tell us something about how the mind can affect the body? @CamplingPenny asks.

Do you keep your home as a haven where you don't discuss fears from COVID, or is it better to get the fear out in the open rather than family members each keeping their fears to themselves, @CamplingPenny asks.

Next up is @CamplingPenny who says we have a choice about how we manage fear. Since the pandemic started I've thought a lot about fear, she says, sharing a story about two clinicians she knows who were particularly fearful of dying from COVID-19 as a result of patient contact.

Human life shows advantages of both agonic and hedonic living. Hedonic life can break down into open warfare in the wrong circumstances - we need to mobilise agonic defences at the right time, Dr Maloney says. Interesting stuff!

Another way of groups living evolved, known as the hedonic mode, where members helped each other, rather than feared each other. This is a happier life, though when times become hard hedonic groups can still turn on each other when times get tough, says Dr Maloney.

Michael Chance was co-author of Social Groups of Monkeys Apes and Men, and was interested in group hierarchies and the way group members interact, Dr Maloney says. The first form of group living he noted was the agonic mode, where your position in the group was based on fear.

Anxiety and fear condition the other emotions we have, says Dr Maloney. The secret is to have enough fear to be vigilant but not to be overwhelmed by it. Being part of groups can help. #RCPsychlectures
And we're off - @DrAdrianJames introduces the three authors of Intelligent Kindness, Dr Chris Maloney, @CamplingPenny and @JohnBallatt - with Chris up first.

We're just minutes away from the first President's lecture of 2021 - and it's on the fascinating topic of how we manage fear, and whether we could do it better. 
https://t.co/fDHZiCpYMR
